info.title: BatchService
info.description: A client for issuing REST requests to the Azure Batch service.

get.summary: Lists all of the applications available in the specified account.

parameters.name: maxresults
parameters.description: The maximum number of items to return in the response.

parameters.name: timeout
parameters.description: The maximum time that the server can spend processing the request, in seconds. The default is 30 seconds.

parameters.name: client-request-id
parameters.description: The caller-generated request identity, in the form of a GUID with no decoration such as curly braces, e.g. 9C4D50EE-2D56-4CD3-8152-34347DC9F2B0.

parameters.name: return-client-request-id
parameters.description: Whether the server should return the client-request-id identifier in the response.

parameters.name: ocp-date
parameters.description: The time the request was issued. If not specified, this header will be automatically populated with the current system clock time.

client-request-id.description: The ClientRequestId provided by the client during the request, if present and requested to be returned.

request-id.description: The value that uniquely identifies a request.

ETag.description: The content of the ETag HTTP response header.

Last-Modified.description: The content of the Last-Modified HTTP response header.

default.description: The error from the Batch service.

get.summary: Lists the usage metrics, aggregated by pool across individual time intervals, for the specified account.

parameters.name: starttime
parameters.description: The earliest time from which to include metrics. This must be at least two and a half hours before the current time.

parameters.name: endtime
parameters.description: The latest time from which to include metrics. This must be at least two hours before the current time.

delete.summary: Deletes the specified task file from the compute node where the task ran.

parameters.name: jobId
parameters.description: The id of the job that contains the task.

parameters.name: taskId
parameters.description: The id of the task whose file you want to delete.

parameters.name: fileName
parameters.description: The path to the task file that you want to delete.

parameters.name: recursive
parameters.description: Whether to delete children of a directory. If the fileName parameter represents a directory instead of a file, you can set Recursive to true to delete the directory and all of the files and subdirectories in it. If Recursive is false then the directory must be empty or deletion will fail.

parameters.name: timeout
parameters.description: The maximum time that the server can spend processing the request, in seconds. The default is 30 seconds.

parameters.name: client-request-id
parameters.description: The caller-generated request identity, in the form of a GUID with no decoration such as curly braces, e.g. 9C4D50EE-2D56-4CD3-8152-34347DC9F2B0.

parameters.description: The time the request was issued. If not specified, this header will be automatically populated with the current system clock time.

poolId.title: The id of the pool whose metrics are aggregated in this entry.

startTime.title: The start time of the aggregation interval covered by this entry.

endTime.title: The end time of the aggregation interval for this entry.

vmSize.title: The size of virtual machines in the pool. All VMs in a pool are the same size.
vmSize.description: For information about available sizes of virtual machines for Cloud Services pools (pools created with cloudServiceConfiguration), see Sizes for Cloud Services (http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/cloud-services-sizes-specs/). Batch supports all Cloud Services VM sizes except ExtraSmall. For information about available VM sizes for pools using images from the Virtual Machines Marketplace (pools created with virtualMachineConfiguration) see Sizes for Virtual Machines (Linux) (https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/virtual-machines-linux-sizes/) or Sizes for Virtual Machines (Windows) (https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/virtual-machines-windows-sizes/). Batch supports all Azure VM sizes except STANDARD_A0 and those with premium storage (STANDARD_GS, STANDARD_DS, and STANDARD_DSV2 series).

totalCoreHours.title: The total core hours used in the pool during this aggregation interval.

dataIngressGiB.title: The cross data center network ingress to the pool during this interval, in GiB.

dataEgressGiB.title: The cross data center network egress from the pool during this interval, in GiB.

PoolUsageMetrics.title: Usage metrics for a pool across an aggregation interval.

odata.nextLink.title: The URL to get the next set of results.

PoolListPoolUsageMetricsResult.title: The result of a listing the usage metrics for an account.

id.title: The id of the node agent SKU.

verifiedImageReferences.title: The list of images verified to be compatible with this node agent SKU.
verifiedImageReferences.description: This collection is not exhaustive (the node agent may be compatible with other images).

osType.title: The type of operating system (Windows/Linux) compatible with the node agent SKU.

NodeAgentSku.title: A node agent SKU supported by the Batch service.
NodeAgentSku.description: The Batch node agent is a program that runs on each node in the pool, and provides the command-and-control interface between the node and the Batch service. There are different implementations of the node agent, known as SKUs, for different operating systems.

value.title: The list of supported node agent SKUs.

odata.nextLink.title: The URL to get the next set of results.

AccountListNodeAgentSkusResult.title: The result of listing the supported node agent SKUs.

startTime.title: The start time of the time range covered by the statistics.

lastUpdateTime.title: The time at which the statistics were last updated. All statistics are limited to the range between startTime and lastUpdateTime.

dedicatedCoreTime.title: The aggregated wall-clock time of the dedicated compute node cores being part of the pool.

UsageStatistics.title: Statistics related to pool usage information.

startTime.title: The start time of the time range covered by the statistics.

lastUpdateTime.title: The time at which the statistics were last updated. All statistics are limited to the range between startTime and lastUpdateTime.

avgCPUPercentage.title: The average CPU usage across all nodes in the pool (percentage per node).

avgMemoryGiB.title: The average memory usage in GiB across all nodes in the pool.

peakMemoryGiB.title: The peak memory usage in GiB across all nodes in the pool.

avgDiskGiB.title: The average used disk space in GiB across all nodes in the pool.

peakDiskGiB.title: The peak used disk space in GiB across all nodes in the pool.

diskReadIOps.title: The total number of disk read operations across all nodes in the pool.

diskWriteIOps.title: The total number of disk write operations across all nodes in the pool.

diskReadGiB.title: The total amount of data in GiB of disk reads across all nodes in the pool.

diskWriteGiB.title: The total amount of data in GiB of disk writes across all nodes in the pool.

networkReadGiB.title: The total amount of data in GiB of network reads across all nodes in the pool.

networkWriteGiB.title: The total amount of data in GiB of network writes across all nodes in the pool.

ResourceStatistics.title: Statistics related to resource consumption by compute nodes in a pool.

startTime.title: The start time of the time range covered by the statistics.

lastUpdateTime.title: The time at which the statistics were last updated. All statistics are limited to the range between startTime and lastUpdateTime.

usageStats.title: Statistics related to pool usage, such as the amount of core-time used.

resourceStats.title: Statistics related to resource consumption by compute nodes in the pool.

PoolStatistics.title: Contains utilization and resource usage statistics for the lifetime of a pool.

startTime.title: The start time of the time range covered by the statistics.

lastUpdateTime.title: The time at which the statistics were last updated. All statistics are limited to the range between startTime and lastUpdateTime.

userCPUTime.title: The total user mode CPU time (summed across all cores and all compute nodes) consumed by all tasks in the job.

kernelCPUTime.title: The total kernel mode CPU time (summed across all cores and all compute nodes) consumed by all tasks in the job.

wallClockTime.title: The total wall clock time of all tasks in the job.

readIOps.title: The total number of disk read operations made by all tasks in the job.

writeIOps.title: The total number of disk write operations made by all tasks in the job.

readIOGiB.title: The total amount of data in GiB read from disk by all tasks in the job.

writeIOGiB.title: The total amount of data in GiB written to disk by all tasks in the job.

numSucceededTasks.title: The total number of tasks successfully completed in the job during the given time range.
numSucceededTasks.description: A task completes successfully if it returns exit code 0.

numFailedTasks.title: The total number of tasks in the job that failed during the given time range.
numFailedTasks.description: A task fails if it exhausts its maximum retry count without returning exit code 0.

numTaskRetries.title: The total number of retries on all the tasks in the job during the given time range.

waitTime.title: The total wait time of all tasks in the job.
waitTime.description: The wait time for a task is defined as the elapsed time between the creation of the task and the start of task execution. (If the task is retried due to failures, the wait time is the time to the most recent task execution.) This value is only reported in the account lifetime statistics; it is not included in the job statistics.

JobStatistics.title: Resource usage statistics for a job.

name.title: The name in the name-value pair.

value.title: The value in the name-value pair.

code.title: An identifier for the certificate deletion error. Codes are invariant and are intended to be consumed programmatically.

message.title: A message describing the certificate deletion error, intended to be suitable for display in a user interface.

values.title: A list of additional error details related to the certificate deletion error.
values.description: This list includes details such as the active pools and nodes referencing this certificate. However, if a large number of resources reference the certificate, the list contains only about the first hundred.

DeleteCertificateError.title: An error encountered by the Batch service when deleting a certificate.

thumbprint.title: The X.509 thumbprint of the certificate. This is a sequence of up to 40 hex digits.

thumbprintAlgorithm.title: The algorithm used to derive the thumbprint.

state.title: The current state of the certificate.

stateTransitionTime.title: The time at which the certificate entered its current state.

previousState.title: The previous state of the certificate.
previousState.description: This property is not set if the certificate is in its initial Active state.

previousStateTransitionTime.title: The time at which the certificate entered its previous state.
previousStateTransitionTime.description: This property is not set if the certificate is in its initial Active state.

publicData.title: The public part of the certificate as a base-64 encoded .cer file.

deleteCertificateError.title: The error that occurred on the last attempt to delete this certificate.
deleteCertificateError.description: This property is set only if the certificate is in the DeleteFailed state.

Certificate.description: A certificate that can be installed on compute nodes and can be used to authenticate operations on the machine.

applicationId.title: The id of the application to deploy.

version.title: The version of the application to deploy. If omitted, the default version is deployed.
version.description: If this is omitted, and no default version is specified for this application, the request fails with the error code InvalidApplicationPackageReferences. If you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 409.

ApplicationPackageReference.title: A reference to an application package to be deployed to compute nodes.

id.title: A string that uniquely identifies the application within the account.

displayName.title: The display name for the application.

versions.title: The versions of the application which are available.

ApplicationSummary.title: Contains information about an application in an Azure Batch account.

thumbprint.title: The X.509 thumbprint of the certificate. This is a sequence of up to 40 hex digits (it may include spaces but these are removed).

thumbprintAlgorithm.title: The algorithm used to derive the thumbprint. This must be sha1.

data.title: The base64-encoded contents of the certificate. The maximum size is 10KB.

certificateFormat.title: The format of the certificate data.

password.title: The password to access the certificate's private key.
password.description: This is required if the certificate format is pfx. It should be omitted if the certificate format is cer.

CertificateAddParameter.title: A certificate that can be installed on compute nodes and can be used to authenticate operations on the machine.

odata.nextLink.title: The URL to get the next set of results.

CertificateListResult.title: The result of listing the certificates in the account.

creationTime.title: The file creation time.
creationTime.description: The creation time is not returned for files on Linux compute nodes.

lastModified.title: The time at which the file was last modified.

contentType.title: The content type of the file.

fileMode.title: The file mode attribute in octal format.
fileMode.description: The file mode is returned only for files on Linux compute nodes.

FileProperties.title: The properties of a file on a compute node.

isDirectory.title: Whether the object represents a directory.

NodeFile.title: Information about a file or directory on a compute node.

odata.nextLink.title: The URL to get the next set of results.

NodeFileListResult.title: The result of listing the files on a compute node, or the files associated with a task on a node.

doNotRunUntil.title: The earliest time at which any job may be created under this job schedule.
doNotRunUntil.description: If you do not specify a doNotRunUntil time, the schedule becomes ready to create jobs immediately.

doNotRunAfter.title: A time after which no job will be created under this job schedule. The schedule will move to the completed state as soon as this deadline is past and there is no active job under this job schedule.
doNotRunAfter.description: If you do not specify a doNotRunAfter time, and you are creating a recurring job schedule, the job schedule will remain active until you explicitly terminate it.

startWindow.title: The time interval, starting from the time at which the schedule indicates a job should be created, within which a job must be created.
startWindow.description: If a job is not created within the startWindow interval, then the 'opportunity' is lost; no job will be created until the next recurrence of the schedule. If the schedule is recurring, and the startWindow is longer than the recurrence interval, then this is equivalent to an infinite startWindow, because the job that is 'due' in one recurrence interval is not carried forward into the next recurrence interval. The default is infinite. The minimum value is 1 minute. If you specify a lower value, the Batch service rejects the schedule with an error; if you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 400 (Bad Request).

recurrenceInterval.title: The time interval between the start times of two successive jobs under the job schedule. A job schedule can have at most one active job under it at any given time.
recurrenceInterval.description: Because a job schedule can have at most one active job under it at any given time, if it is time to create a new job under a job schedule, but the previous job is still running, the Batch service will not create the new job until the previous job finishes. If the previous job does not finish within the startWindow period of the new recurrence interval, then no new job will be scheduled for that interval. For recurring jobs, you should normally specify a jobManagerTask in the jobSpecification. If you do not use jobManagerTask, you will need an external process to monitor when jobs are created, add tasks to the jobs and terminate the jobs ready for the next recurrence. The default is that the schedule does not recur: one job is created, within the startWindow after the doNotRunUntil time, and the schedule is complete as soon as that job finishes. The minimum value is 1 minute. If you specify a lower value, the Batch service rejects the schedule with an error; if you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 400 (Bad Request).

Schedule.title: The schedule according to which jobs will be created

maxWallClockTime.title: The maximum elapsed time that the job may run, measured from the time the job is created. If the job does not complete within the time limit, the Batch service terminates it and any tasks that are still running. In this case, the termination reason will be MaxWallClockTimeExpiry.
maxWallClockTime.description: If this is not specified, there is no time limit on how long the job may run.

maxTaskRetryCount.title: The maximum number of times each task may be retried. The Batch service retries a task if its exit code is nonzero.
maxTaskRetryCount.description: Note that this value specifically controls the number of retries. The Batch service will try each task once, and may then retry up to this limit. For example, if the maximum retry count is 3, Batch tries a task up to 4 times (one initial try and 3 retries). If the maximum retry count is 0, the Batch service does not retry tasks. If the maximum retry count is -1, the Batch service retries tasks without limit. The default value is 0 (no retries).

JobConstraints.title: Specifies the execution constraints for a job.

blobSource.title: The URL of the file within Azure Blob Storage.
blobSource.description: This URL must be readable using anonymous access; that is, the Batch service does not present any credentials when downloading the blob. There are two ways to get such a URL for a blob in Azure storage: include a Shared Access Signature (SAS) granting read permissions on the blob, or set the ACL for the blob or its container to allow public access.

filePath.title: The location on the compute node to which to download the file, relative to the task's working directory.

fileMode.title: The file permission mode attribute in octal format.
fileMode.description: This property applies only to files being downloaded to Linux compute nodes. It will be ignored if it is specified for a resourceFile which will be downloaded to a Windows node. If this property is not specified for a Linux node, then a default value of 0770 is applied to the file.

ResourceFile.title: A file to be downloaded from Azure blob storage to a compute node.

name.title: The name of the environment variable.

value.title: The value of the environment variable.

EnvironmentSetting.title: An environment variable to be set on a task process.

exitCodes.title: A list of individual task exit codes and how the Batch service should respond to them.

exitCodeRanges.title: A list of task exit code ranges and how the Batch service should respond to them.

schedulingError.title: How the Batch service should respond if the task fails with a scheduling error.

default.title: How the Batch service should respond if the task fails with an exit condition not covered by any of the other properties – that is, any nonzero exit code not listed in the exitCodes or exitCodeRanges collection, or a scheduling error if the schedulingError property is not present.
default.description: Note that the default condition does not include exit code 0. If you want non-default behaviour on exit code 0, you must list it explicitly using the exitCodes or exitCodeRanges collection.

ExitConditions.title: Specifies how the Batch service should respond when the task completes.

exitOptions.title: How the Batch service should respond if the task exits with this exit code.

ExitCodeMapping.title: How the Batch service should respond if a task exits with a particular exit code.

start.title: The first exit code in the range.

end.title: The last exit code in the range.

exitOptions.title: An exitOptions specifying how the Batch service should respond if the task exits with an exit code in the range start to end (inclusive).

ExitCodeRangeMapping.title: A range of exit codes and how the Batch service should respond to exit codes within that range.

jobAction.title: An action to take on the job containing the task, if the task completes with the given exit condition and the job’s onTaskFailed property is 'performexitoptionsjobaction'.
jobAction.description: The default is none for exit code 0 and terminate for all other exit conditions. It is an error to specify this if the job's onTaskFailed is noaction. The add task request fails with an invalid property value error; if you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 400 (Bad Request).

ExitOptions.title: How the Batch service should respond to a particular exit condition.

maxWallClockTime.title: The maximum elapsed time that the task may run, measured from the time the task starts. If the task does not complete within the time limit, the Batch service terminates it.
maxWallClockTime.description: If this is not specified, there is no time limit on how long the task may run.

retentionTime.title: The minimum time to retain the working directory for the task on the compute node where it ran, from the time it completes execution. After this time, the Batch service may delete the working directory and all its contents.
retentionTime.description: The default is infinite, i.e. the working directory will be retained until the compute node is removed or reimaged.

maxTaskRetryCount.title: The maximum number of times the task may be retried. The Batch service retries a task if its exit code is nonzero.
maxTaskRetryCount.description: Note that this value specifically controls the number of retries. The Batch service will try the task once, and may then retry up to this limit. For example, if the maximum retry count is 3, Batch tries the task up to 4 times (one initial try and 3 retries). If the maximum retry count is 0, the Batch service does not retry the task. If the maximum retry count is -1, the Batch service retries the task without limit.

TaskConstraints.title: Execution constraints to apply to a task.

id.title: A string that uniquely identifies the Job Manager taskwithin the job.
id.description: The id can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters including hyphens and underscores and cannot contain more than 64 characters.

displayName.title: The display name of the Job Manager task.
displayName.description: It need not be unique and can contain any Unicode characters up to a maximum length of 1024.

commandLine.title: The command line of the Job Manager task.
commandLine.description: The command line does not run under a shell, and therefore cannot take advantage of shell features such as environment variable expansion. If you want to take advantage of such features, you should invoke the shell in the command line, for example using "cmd /c MyCommand" in Windows or "/bin/sh -c MyCommand" in Linux.

resourceFiles.title: A list of files that the Batch service will download to the compute node before running the command line.
resourceFiles.description: Files listed under this element are located in the task's wd directory.

environmentSettings.title: A list of environment variable settings for the Job Manager task.

constraints.title: Constraints that apply to the Job Manager task.

killJobOnCompletion.title: Whether completion of the Job Manager task signifies completion of the entire job.
killJobOnCompletion.description: If true, when the Job Manager task completes, the Batch service marks the job as complete. If any tasks are still running at this time (other than Job Release), those tasks are terminated. If false, the completion of the Job Manager task does not affect the job status. In this case, you should either use the onAllTasksComplete attribute to terminate the job, or have a client or user terminate the job explicitly. An example of this is if the Job Manager creates a set of tasks but then takes no further role in their execution. The default value is true. If you are using the onAllTasksComplete and onTaskFailure attributes to control job lifetime, and using the job manager task only to create the tasks for the job (not to monitor progress), then it is important to set killJobOnCompletion to false.

runElevated.title: Whether to run the Job Manager task in elevated mode. The default value is false.

runExclusive.title: Whether the Job Manager task requires exclusive use of the compute node where it runs.
runExclusive.description: If true, no other tasks will run on the same compute node for as long as the Job Manager is running. If false, other tasks can run simultaneously with the Job Manager on a compute node. The Job Manager task counts normally against the node's concurrent task limit, so this is only relevant if the node allows multiple concurrent tasks. The default value is true.

applicationPackageReferences.title: A list of application packages that the Batch service will deploy to the compute node before running the command line.
applicationPackageReferences.description: Application packages are downloaded and deployed to a shared directory, not the task directory. Therefore, if a referenced package is already on the compute node, and is up to date, then it is not re-downloaded; the existing copy on the compute node is used. If a referenced application package cannot be installed, for example because the package has been deleted or because download failed, the task fails with a scheduling error. This property is currently not supported on jobs running on pools created using the virtualMachineConfiguration (IaaS) property. If a task specifying applicationPackageReferences runs on such a pool, it fails with a scheduling error with code TaskSchedulingConstraintFailed.

JobManagerTask.title: Specifies details of a Job Manager task.

id.title: A string that uniquely identifies the job preparation task within the job.
id.description: The id can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters including hyphens and underscores and cannot contain more than 64 characters. If you do not specify this property, the Batch service assigns a default value of 'jobpreparation'. No other task in the job can have the same id as the Job Preparation task. If you try to submit a task with the same id, the Batch service rejects the request with error code TaskIdSameAsJobPreparationTask; if you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 409 (Conflict).

commandLine.title: The command line of the Job Preparation task.
commandLine.description: The command line does not run under a shell, and therefore cannot take advantage of shell features such as environment variable expansion. If you want to take advantage of such features, you should invoke the shell in the command line, for example using "cmd /c MyCommand" in Windows or "/bin/sh -c MyCommand" in Linux.

resourceFiles.title: A list of files that the Batch service will download to the compute node before running the command line.
resourceFiles.description: Files listed under this element are located in the task's wd directory.

environmentSettings.title: A list of environment variable settings for the Job Preparation task.

constraints.title: Constraints that apply to the Job Preparation task.

waitForSuccess.title: Whether the Batch service should wait for the Job Preparation task to complete successfully before scheduling any other tasks of the job on the compute node.
waitForSuccess.description: If true and the Job Preparation task fails on a compute node, the Batch service retries the Job Preparation task up to its maximum retry count (as specified in the constraints element). If the task has still not completed successfully after all retries, then the Batch service will not schedule tasks of the job to the compute node. The compute node remains active and eligible to run tasks of other jobs. If false, the Batch service will not wait for the Job Preparation task to complete. In this case, other tasks of the job can start executing on the compute node while the Job Preparation task is still running; and even if the Job Preparation task fails, new tasks will continue to be scheduled on the node. The default value is true.

runElevated.title: Whether to run the Job Preparation task in elevated mode. The default value is false.

rerunOnNodeRebootAfterSuccess.title: Whether the Batch service should rerun the Job Preparation task after a compute node reboots.
rerunOnNodeRebootAfterSuccess.description: The Job Preparation task is always rerun if a compute node is reimaged, or if the Job Preparation task did not complete (e.g. because the reboot occurred while the task was running). Therefore, you should always write a Job Preparation task to be idempotent and to behave correctly if run multiple times. The default value is true.

JobPreparationTask.title: A Job Preparation task to run before any tasks of the job on any given compute node.

id.title: A string that uniquely identifies the Job Release task within the job.
id.description: The id can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters including hyphens and underscores and cannot contain more than 64 characters. If you do not specify this property, the Batch service assigns a default value of 'jobrelease'. No other task in the job can have the same id as the Job Release task. If you try to submit a task with the same id, the Batch service rejects the request with error code TaskIdSameAsJobReleaseTask; if you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 409 (Conflict).

commandLine.title: The command line of the Job Release task.
commandLine.description: The command line does not run under a shell, and therefore cannot take advantage of shell features such as environment variable expansion. If you want to take advantage of such features, you should invoke the shell in the command line, for example using "cmd /c MyCommand" in Windows or "/bin/sh -c MyCommand" in Linux.

resourceFiles.title: A list of files that the Batch service will download to the compute node before running the command line.
resourceFiles.description: Files listed under this element are located in the task's wd directory.

environmentSettings.title: A list of environment variable settings for the Job Release task.

maxWallClockTime.title: The maximum elapsed time that the Job Release task may run on a given compute node, measured from the time the task starts. If the task does not complete within the time limit, the Batch service terminates it. The default value is 15 minutes. You may not specify a timeout longer than 15 minutes. If you do, the Batch service rejects it with an error; if you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 400 (Bad Request).

retentionTime.title: The minimum time to retain the working directory for the Job Release task on the compute node. After this time, the Batch service may delete the working directory and all its contents.
retentionTime.description: The default is infinite, i.e. the working directory will be retained until the compute node is removed or reimaged.

runElevated.title: Whether to run the Job Release task in elevated mode.

JobReleaseTask.title: A Job Release task to run on job completion on any compute node where the job has run.

nodeFillType.title: How tasks should be distributed across compute nodes

TaskSchedulingPolicy.title: Specifies how tasks should be distributed across compute nodes.

commandLine.title: The command line of the start task.
commandLine.description: The command line does not run under a shell, and therefore cannot take advantage of shell features such as environment variable expansion. If you want to take advantage of such features, you should invoke the shell in the command line, for example using "cmd /c MyCommand" in Windows or "/bin/sh -c MyCommand" in Linux.

resourceFiles.title: A list of files that the Batch service will download to the compute node before running the command line.

environmentSettings.title: A list of environment variable settings for the start task.

runElevated.title: Whether to run the start task in elevated mode. The default value is false.

maxTaskRetryCount.title: The maximum number of times the task may be retried.
maxTaskRetryCount.description: The Batch service retries a task if its exit code is nonzero. Note that this value specifically controls the number of retries. The Batch service will try the task once, and may then retry up to this limit. For example, if the maximum retry count is 3, Batch tries the task up to 4 times (one initial try and 3 retries). If the maximum retry count is 0, the Batch service does not retry the task. If the maximum retry count is -1, the Batch service retries the task without limit.

waitForSuccess.title: Whether the Batch service should wait for the start task to complete successfully (that is, to exit with exit code 0) before scheduling any tasks on the compute node.
waitForSuccess.description: If true and the start task fails on a compute node, the Batch service retries the start task up to its maximum retry count (maxTaskRetryCount). If the task has still not completed successfully after all retries, then the Batch service marks the compute node unusable, and will not schedule tasks to it. This condition can be detected via the node state and scheduling error detail. If false, the Batch service will not wait for the start task to complete. In this case, other tasks can start executing on the compute node while the start task is still running; and even if the start task fails, new tasks will continue to be scheduled on the node. The default is false.

StartTask.title: A task which is run when a compute node joins a pool in the Azure Batch service, or when the compute node is rebooted or reimaged.

thumbprintAlgorithm.title: The algorithm with which the thumbprint is associated. This must be sha1.

storeLocation.title: The location of the certificate store on the compute node into which to install the certificate.
storeLocation.description: The default value is CurrentUser. This property is applicable only for pools created with cloudServiceConfiguration (PaaS) or virtualMachineConfiguration (IaaS) Windows nodes. For Linux compute nodes, the certificates are stored in a directory inside the task working directory and an environment variable AZ_BATCH_CERTIFICATES_DIR is supplied to the task to query for this location. For certificates with visibility of remoteuser, a certs directory is created in the user's home directory (e.g., /home/<user-name>/certs) where certificates are placed.

storeName.title: The name of the certificate store on the compute node into which to install the certificate.
storeName.description: The default value is My. This property is applicable only for pools created with cloudServiceConfiguration (PaaS) or virtualMachineConfiguration (IaaS) Windows nodes.

visibility.title: Which user accounts on the compute node should have access to the private data of the certificate.

CertificateReference.title: A reference to a certificate to be installed on compute nodes in a pool.

name.title: The name of the metadata item.

value.title: The value of the metadata item.

MetadataItem.title: A name-value pair associated with a Batch service resource.
MetadataItem.description: The Batch service does not assign any meaning to this metadata; it is solely for the use of user code.

displayName.title: The display name for the pool.
displayName.description: The display name need not be unique and can contain any Unicode characters up to a maximum length of 1024.

vmSize.title: The size of the virtual machines in the pool. All virtual machines in a pool are the same size.
vmSize.description: For information about available sizes of virtual machines for Cloud Services pools (pools created with cloudServiceConfiguration), see Sizes for Cloud Services (http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/cloud-services-sizes-specs/). Batch supports all Cloud Services VM sizes except ExtraSmall. For information about available VM sizes for pools using images from the Virtual Machines Marketplace (pools created with virtualMachineConfiguration) see Sizes for Virtual Machines (Linux) (https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/virtual-machines-linux-sizes/) or Sizes for Virtual Machines (Windows) (https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/virtual-machines-windows-sizes/). Batch supports all Azure VM sizes except STANDARD_A0 and those with premium storage (STANDARD_GS, STANDARD_DS, and STANDARD_DSV2 series).

cloudServiceConfiguration.title: The cloud service configuration for the pool.
cloudServiceConfiguration.description: This property must be specified if the pool needs to be created with Azure PaaS VMs. This property and VirtualMachineConfiguration are mutually exclusive and one of the properties must be specified. If neither is specified then the Batch service returns an error; if you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 400 (Bad Request).

virtualMachineConfiguration.title: The virtual machine configuration for the pool.
virtualMachineConfiguration.description: This property must be specified if the pool needs to be created with Azure IaaS VMs. This property and CloudServiceConfiguration are mutually exclusive and one of the properties must be specified. If neither is specified then the Batch service returns an error; if you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 400 (Bad Request).

maxTasksPerNode.title: The maximum number of tasks that can run concurrently on a single compute node in the pool.
maxTasksPerNode.description: The default value is 1. The maximum value of this setting depends on the size of the compute nodes in the pool (the vmSize setting).

taskSchedulingPolicy.description: How tasks are distributed among compute nodes in the pool.

resizeTimeout.title: The timeout for allocation of compute nodes to the pool.
resizeTimeout.description: This timeout applies only to manual scaling; it has no effect when enableAutoScale is set to true. The default value is 15 minutes. The minimum value is 5 minutes. If you specify a value less than 5 minutes, the Batch service rejects the request with an error; if you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 400 (Bad Request).

targetDedicated.title: The desired number of compute nodes in the pool.
targetDedicated.description: This property must not be specified if enableAutoScale is set to true. It is required if enableAutoScale is set to false.

enableAutoScale.title: Whether the pool size should automatically adjust over time.
enableAutoScale.description: If false, the targetDedicated element is required. If true, the autoScaleFormula element is required. The pool automatically resizes according to the formula. The default value is false.

autoScaleFormula.title: The formula for the desired number of compute nodes in the pool.
autoScaleFormula.description: This property must not be specified if enableAutoScale is set to false. It is required if enableAutoScale is set to true. The formula is checked for validity before the pool is created. If the formula is not valid, the Batch service rejects the request with detailed error information.

autoScaleEvaluationInterval.title: The time interval at which to automatically adjust the pool size according to the autoscale formula.
autoScaleEvaluationInterval.description: The default value is 15 minutes. The minimum and maximum value are 5 minutes and 168 hours respectively. If you specify a value less than 5 minutes or greater than 168 hours, the Batch service rejects the request with an invalid property value error; if you are calling the REST API directly, the HTTP status code is 400 (Bad Request).

enableInterNodeCommunication.title: Whether the pool permits direct communication between nodes.

networkConfiguration.title: The network configuration for the pool.

startTask.title: A task to run on each compute node as it joins the pool. The task runs when the node is added to the pool or when the node is restarted.

certificateReferences.title: A list of certificates to be installed on each compute node in the pool.
certificateReferences.description: Each certificate in the list must have been previously added to the Batch account.

applicationPackageReferences.title: The list of application packages to be installed on each compute node in the pool.
applicationPackageReferences.description: This property is currently not supported on auto pools created with the virtualMachineConfiguration (IaaS) property.

metadata.title: A list of name-value pairs associated with the pool as metadata.
metadata.description: The Batch service does not assign any meaning to metadata; it is solely for the use of user code.

PoolSpecification.title: Specification for creating a new pool.

autoPoolIdPrefix.title: A prefix to be added to the unique identifier when a pool is automatically created.
autoPoolIdPrefix.description: The Batch service assigns each auto pool a unique identifier on creation. To distinguish between pools created for different purposes, you can specify this element to add a prefix to the id that is assigned. The prefix can be up to 20 characters long.

poolLifetimeOption.title: The minimum lifetime of created auto pools, and how multiple jobs on a schedule are assigned to pools.

keepAlive.title: Whether to keep an auto pool alive after its lifetime expires.
keepAlive.description: If false, the Batch service deletes the pool once its lifetime (as determined by the poolLifetimeOption setting) expires; that is, when the job or job schedule completes. If true, the Batch service does not delete the pool automatically. It is up to the user to delete auto pools created with this option.

pool.title: The pool specification for the auto pool.

AutoPoolSpecification.title: Specifies characteristics for a temporary 'auto pool'. The Batch service will create this auto pool when the job is submitted.

poolId.title: The id of an existing pool. All the tasks of the job will run on the specified pool.
poolId.description: You must specify either poolId or autoPoolSpecification, but not both.

autoPoolSpecification.title: Characteristics for a temporary 'auto pool'. The Batch service will create this auto pool and run all the tasks of the job will run on it, and will delete the pool once the job has completed (subject to the auto pool settings).
autoPoolSpecification.description: You must specify either poolId or autoPoolSpecification, but not both.

PoolInformation.title: Specifies how a job should be assigned to a pool.

priority.title: The priority of jobs created under this schedule.
priority.description: Priority values can range from -1000 to 1000, with -1000 being the lowest priority and 1000 being the highest priority. The default value is 0.

displayName.title: The display name for jobs created under this schedule.
displayName.description: The name need not be unique and can contain any Unicode characters up to a maximum length of 1024.

usesTaskDependencies.title: The flag that determines if this job will use tasks with dependencies.

onAllTasksComplete.title: The action the Batch service should take when all tasks in a job created under this schedule are in the completed state.
onAllTasksComplete.description: Note that if a job contains no tasks, then all tasks are considered complete. This option is therefore most commonly used with a job manager task; if you want to use automatic job termination without a job manager, you should initially set onAllTasksComplete to noaction and update the job properties to set onAllTasksComplete to terminatejob once you have finished adding tasks. The default is noaction.

onTaskFailure.title: The action the Batch service should take when any task fails in a job created under this schedule. A task is considered to have failed if it completes with a non-zero exit code and has exhausted its retry count, or if it had a scheduling error.

constraints.title: The execution constraints for jobs created under this schedule.

jobManagerTask.title: The details of a Job Manager task to be launched when a job is started under this schedule.
jobManagerTask.description: If the job does not specify a Job Manager task, the user must explicitly add tasks to the job using the Task API. If the job does specify a Job Manager task, the Batch service creates the Job Manager task when the job is created, and will try to schedule the Job Manager task before scheduling other tasks in the job.

jobPreparationTask.title: The Job Preparation task for jobs created under this schedule.
jobPreparationTask.description: If a job has a Job Preparation task, the Batch service will run the Job Preparation task on a compute node before starting any tasks of that job on that compute node.

jobReleaseTask.title: The Job Release task for jobs created under this schedule.
jobReleaseTask.description: The primary purpose of the Job Release task is to undo changes to compute nodes made by the Job Preparation task. Example activities include deleting local files, or shutting down services that were started as part of job preparation. A Job Release task cannot be specified without also specifying a Job Preparation task for the job. The Batch service runs the Job Release task on the compute nodes that have run the Job Preparation task.

commonEnvironmentSettings.title: A list of common environment variable settings. These environment variables are set for all tasks in jobs created under this schedule (including the Job Manager, Job Preparation and Job Release tasks).
commonEnvironmentSettings.description: Individual tasks can override an environment setting specified here by specifying the same setting name with a different value.

poolInfo.title: The pool on which the Batch service runs the tasks of jobs created under this schedule.

metadata.title: A list of name-value pairs associated with each job created under this schedule as metadata.
metadata.description: The Batch service does not assign any meaning to metadata; it is solely for the use of user code.

JobSpecification.title: Specifies details of the jobs to be created on a schedule.

RecentJob.title: Information about the most recent job to run under the job schedule.

nextRunTime.title: The next time at which a job will be created under this schedule.
nextRunTime.description: This property is meaningful only if the schedule is in the active state when the time comes around. For example, if the schedule is disabled, no job will be created at nextRunTime unless the job is enabled before then.

recentJob.title: Information about the most recent job under the job schedule.
recentJob.description: This property is present only if the at least one job has run under the schedule.

endTime.title: The time at which the schedule ended.
endTime.description: This property is set only if the job schedule is in the completed state.

JobScheduleExecutionInformation.title: Contains information about jobs that have been and will be run under a job schedule.

startTime.title: The start time of the time range covered by the statistics.

lastUpdateTime.title: The time at which the statistics were last updated. All statistics are limited to the range between startTime and lastUpdateTime.

userCPUTime.title: The total user mode CPU time (summed across all cores and all compute nodes) consumed by all tasks in all jobs created under the schedule.

kernelCPUTime.title: The total kernel mode CPU time (summed across all cores and all compute nodes) consumed by all tasks in all jobs created under the schedule.

wallClockTime.title: The total wall clock time of all the tasks in all the jobs created under the schedule.
wallClockTime.description: The wall clock time is the elapsed time from when the task started running on a compute node to when it finished (or to the last time the statistics were updated, if the task had not finished by then). If a task was retried, this includes the wall clock time of all the task retries.

readIOps.title: The total number of disk read operations made by all tasks in all jobs created under the schedule.

writeIOps.title: The total number of disk write operations made by all tasks in all jobs created under the schedule.

readIOGiB.title: The total gibibytes read from disk by all tasks in all jobs created under the schedule.

writeIOGiB.title: The total gibibytes written to disk by all tasks in all jobs created under the schedule.

numSucceededTasks.title: The total number of tasks successfully completed during the given time range in jobs created under the schedule. A task completes successfully if it returns exit code 0.

numFailedTasks.title: The total number of tasks that failed during the given time range in jobs created under the schedule. A task fails if it exhausts its maximum retry count without returning exit code 0.

numTaskRetries.title: The total number of retries during the given time range on all tasks in all jobs created under the schedule.

waitTime.title: The total wait time of all tasks in all jobs created under the schedule. The wait time for a task is defined as the elapsed time between the creation of the task and the start of task execution. (If the task is retried due to failures, the wait time is the time to the most recent task execution.)
waitTime.description: This value is only reported in the account lifetime statistics; it is not included in the job statistics.

JobScheduleStatistics.title: Resource usage statistics for a job schedule.

id.title: A string that uniquely identifies the schedule within the account.
id.description: It is common to use a GUID for the id.

displayName.title: The display name for the schedule.

url.title: The URL of the job schedule.

eTag.title: The ETag of the job schedule.
eTag.description: This is an opaque string. You can use it to detect whether the job schedule has changed between requests. In particular, you can be pass the ETag with an Update Job Schedule request to specify that your changes should take effect only if nobody else has modified the schedule in the meantime.

lastModified.title: The last modified time of the job schedule.
lastModified.description: This is the last time at which the schedule level data, such as the job specification or recurrence information, changed. It does not factor in job-level changes such as new jobs being created or jobs changing state.

creationTime.title: The creation time of the job schedule.

state.title: The current state of the job schedule.

stateTransitionTime.title: The time at which the job schedule entered the current state.

previousState.title: The previous state of the job schedule.
previousState.description: This property is not present if the job schedule is in its initial active state.

previousStateTransitionTime.title: The time at which the job schedule entered its previous state.
previousStateTransitionTime.description: This property is not present if the job schedule is in its initial active state.

schedule.title: The schedule according to which jobs will be created.

jobSpecification.title: The details of the jobs to be created on this schedule.

executionInfo.title: Information about jobs that have been and will be run under this schedule.

metadata.title: A list of name-value pairs associated with the schedule as metadata.
metadata.description: The Batch service does not assign any meaning to metadata; it is solely for the use of user code.

stats.title: The lifetime resource usage statistics for the job schedule.

CloudJobSchedule.title: A job schedule that allows recurring jobs by specifying when to run jobs and a specification used to create each job.

id.title: A string that uniquely identifies the schedule within the account.
id.description: The id can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters including hyphens and underscores, and cannot contain more than 64 characters. The id is case-preserving and case-insensitive (that is, you may not have two ids within an account that differ only by case).

displayName.title: The display name for the schedule.
displayName.description: The display name need not be unique and can contain any Unicode characters up to a maximum length of 1024.

schedule.title: The schedule according to which jobs will be created.

jobSpecification.title: The details of the jobs to be created on this schedule.

metadata.title: A list of name-value pairs associated with the schedule as metadata.
metadata.description: The Batch service does not assign any meaning to metadata; it is solely for the use of user code.

JobScheduleAddParameter.title: A job schedule that allows recurring jobs by specifying when to run jobs and a specification used to create each job.

odata.nextLink.title: The URL to get the next set of results.

CloudJobScheduleListResult.title: The result of listing the job schedules in an account.

category.title: The category of the job scheduling error.

code.title: An identifier for the job scheduling error. Codes are invariant and are intended to be consumed programmatically.

message.title: A message describing the job scheduling error, intended to be suitable for display in a user interface.

details.title: A list of additional error details related to the scheduling error.

JobSchedulingError.title: An error encountered by the Batch service when scheduling a job.

startTime.title: The start time of the job.
startTime.description: This is the time at which the job was created.

endTime.title: The completion time of the job.
endTime.description: This property is set only if the job is in the completed state.

poolId.title: The ID of the pool to which this job is assigned.
poolId.description: This element contains the actual pool where the job is assigned. When you get job details from the service, they also contain a poolInfo element, which contains the pool configuration data from when the job was added or updated. That poolInfo element may also contain a poolId element. If it does, the two IDs are the same. If it does not, it means the job ran on an auto pool, and this property contains the id of that auto pool.

schedulingError.title: Details of any error encountered by the service in starting the job.
schedulingError.description: This property is not set if there was no error starting the job.

terminateReason.title: A string describing the reason the job ended.
terminateReason.description: This property is set only if the job is in the completed state. If the Batch service terminates the job, it sets the reason as follows: JMComplete – the Job Manager task completed, and killJobOnCompletion was set to true. MaxWallClockTimeExpiry – the job reached its maxWallClockTime constraint. TerminateJobSchedule – the job ran as part of a schedule, and the schedule terminated. AllTasksComplete – the job's onAllTasksComplete attribute is set to terminatejob, and all tasks in the job are complete. TaskFailed – the job's onTaskFailure attribute is set to performexitoptionsjobaction, and a task in the job failed with an exit condition that specified a jobAction of terminatejob. Any other string is a user-defined reason specified in a call to the 'Terminate a job' operation.

JobExecutionInformation.title: Contains information about the execution of a job in the Azure Batch service.

id.title: A string that uniquely identifies the job within the account.
id.description: The ID can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters including hyphens and underscores, and cannot contain more than 64 characters.

displayName.title: The display name for the job.

usesTaskDependencies.title: The flag that determines if this job will use tasks with dependencies.

eTag.title: The ETag of the job.
eTag.description: This is an opaque string. You can use it to detect whether the job has changed between requests. In particular, you can be pass the ETag when updating a job to specify that your changes should take effect only if nobody else has modified the job in the meantime.

lastModified.title: The last modified time of the job.
lastModified.description: This is the last time at which the job level data, such as the job state or priority, changed. It does not factor in task-level changes such as adding new tasks or tasks changing state.

creationTime.title: The creation time of the job.

state.title: The current state of the job.

stateTransitionTime.title: The time at which the job entered its current state.

previousState.title: The previous state of the job.
previousState.description: This property is not set if the job is in its initial Active state.

previousStateTransitionTime.title: The time at which the job entered its previous state.
previousStateTransitionTime.description: This property is not set if the job is in its initial Active state.

priority.title: The priority of the job.
priority.description: Priority values can range from -1000 to 1000, with -1000 being the lowest priority and 1000 being the highest priority. The default value is 0.

constraints.title: The execution constraints for the job.

jobManagerTask.title: Details of a Job Manager task to be launched when the job is started.

jobPreparationTask.title: The Job Preparation task.
jobPreparationTask.description: The Job Preparation task is a special task run on each node before any other task of the job.

jobReleaseTask.title: The Job Release task.
jobReleaseTask.description: The Job Release task is a special task run at the end of the job on each node that has run any other task of the job.

commonEnvironmentSettings.title: The list of common environment variable settings. These environment variables are set for all tasks in the job (including the Job Manager, Job Preparation and Job Release tasks).

poolInfo.title: The pool settings associated with the job.

onAllTasksComplete.title: The action the Batch service should take when all tasks in the job are in the completed state.
onAllTasksComplete.description: Permitted values are: noaction – do nothing. The job remains active unless terminated or disabled by some other means. terminatejob – terminate the job. The job's terminateReason is set to 'AllTasksComplete'. The default is noaction.

onTaskFailure.title: The action the Batch service should take when any task in the job fails. A task is considered to have failed if it completes with a non-zero exit code and has exhausted its retry count, or if it had a scheduling error.
onTaskFailure.description: Permitted values are: noaction – do nothing. performexitoptionsjobaction – take the action associated with the task exit condition in the task's exitConditions collection. (This may still result in no action being taken, if that is what the task specifies.) The default is noaction.

metadata.title: A list of name-value pairs associated with the job as metadata.
metadata.description: The Batch service does not assign any meaning to metadata; it is solely for the use of user code.

executionInfo.title: The execution information for the job.

stats.title: Resource usage statistics for the entire lifetime of the job.

id.title: A string that uniquely identifies the job within the account.
id.description: The ID can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters including hyphens and underscores, and cannot contain more than 64 characters.

displayName.title: The display name for the job.
displayName.description: The display name need not be unique and can contain any Unicode characters up to a maximum length of 1024.

priority.title: The priority of the job.
priority.description: Priority values can range from -1000 to 1000, with -1000 being the lowest priority and 1000 being the highest priority. The default value is 0.

constraints.description: The execution constraints for the job.

jobManagerTask.title: Details of a Job Manager task to be launched when the job is started.
jobManagerTask.description: If the job does not specify a Job Manager task, the user must explicitly add tasks to the job. If the job does specify a Job Manager task, the Batch service creates the Job Manager task when the job is created, and will try to schedule the Job Manager task before scheduling other tasks in the job. The Job Manager task's typical purpose is to control and/or monitor job execution, for example by deciding what additional tasks to run, determining when the work is complete, etc. (However, a Job Manager task is not restricted to these activities – it is a fully-fledged task in the system and perform whatever actions are required for the job.) For example, a Job Manager task might download a file specified as a parameter, analyze the contents of that file and submit additional tasks based on those contents.

jobPreparationTask.title: The Job Preparation task.
jobPreparationTask.description: If a job has a Job Preparation task, the Batch service will run the Job Preparation task on a compute node before starting any tasks of that job on that compute node.

jobReleaseTask.title: The Job Release task.
jobReleaseTask.description: A Job Release task cannot be specified without also specifying a Job Preparation task for the job. The Batch service runs the Job Release task on the compute nodes that have run the Job Preparation task. The primary purpose of the Job Release task is to undo changes to compute nodes made by the Job Preparation task. Example activities include deleting local files, or shutting down services that were started as part of job preparation.

commonEnvironmentSettings.title: The list of common environment variable settings. These environment variables are set for all tasks in the job (including the Job Manager, Job Preparation and Job Release tasks).

poolInfo.title: The pool on which the Batch service runs the job's tasks.

onAllTasksComplete.title: The action the Batch service should take when all tasks in the job are in the completed state.
onAllTasksComplete.description: Note that if a job contains no tasks, then all tasks are considered complete. This option is therefore most commonly used with a job manager task; if you want to use automatic job termination without a job manager, you should initially set onAllTasksComplete to noaction and update the job properties to set onAllTasksComplete to terminatejob once you have finished adding tasks. Permitted values are: noaction – do nothing. The job remains active unless terminated or disabled by some other means. terminatejob – terminate the job. The job’s terminateReason is set to 'AllTasksComplete'. The default is noaction.

onTaskFailure.title: The action the Batch service should take when any task in the job fails. A task is considered to have failed if it completes with a non-zero exit code and has exhausted its retry count, or if it had a scheduling error.
onTaskFailure.description: Permitted values are: noaction – do nothing. performexitoptionsjobaction – take the action associated with the task exit condition in the task's exitConditions collection. (This may still result in no action being taken, if that is what the task specifies.) The default is noaction.

details.title: The list of additional error details related to the scheduling error.

TaskSchedulingError.title: Information about an error when scheduling a task.

startTime.title: The time at which the task started running.
startTime.description: Note that every time the task is restarted, this value is updated.

endTime.title: The time at which the Job Preparation task completed.
endTime.description: This property is set only if the task is in the Completed state.

state.title: The current state of the Job Preparation task.

taskRootDirectory.title: The root directory of the Job Preparation task on the compute node. You can use this path to retrieve files created by the task, such as log files.

taskRootDirectoryUrl.title: The URL to the root directory of the Job Preparation task on the compute node.

exitCode.title: The exit code of the program specified on the task command line.
exitCode.description: This parameter is returned only if the task is in the completed state. The exit code for a process reflects the specific convention implemented by the application developer for that process. If you use the exit code value to make decisions in your code, be sure that you know the exit code convention used by the application process. Note that the exit code may also be generated by the compute node operating system, such as when a process is forcibly terminated.

schedulingError.title: The error encountered by the Batch service when starting the task.

retryCount.title: The number of times the task has been retried by the Batch service. Every time the task exits with a non-zero exit code, it is deemed a task failure. The Batch service will retry the task up to the limit specified by the constraints.

lastRetryTime.title: The most recent time at which a retry of the Job Preparation task started running.
lastRetryTime.description: This property is set only if the task was retried (i.e. retryCount is nonzero).

JobPreparationTaskExecutionInformation.title: Contains information about the execution of a Job Preparation task on a compute node.

startTime.title: The time at which the task started running. Note that every time the task is restarted, this value is updated.

endTime.title: The time at which the Job Release task completed.

taskRootDirectory.title: The root directory of the Job Release task on the compute node. You can use this path to retrieve files created by the task, such as log files.

exitCode.title: The exit code of the program specified on the task command line.

The exit code for a process reflects the specific convention implemented by the application developer for that process. If you use the exit code value to make decisions in your code, be sure that you know the exit code convention used by the application process. Note that the exit code may also be generated by the compute node operating system, such as when a process is forcibly terminated.

schedulingError.title: The scheduling error encountered by the Batch service when starting the task.

JobReleaseTaskExecutionInformation.title: Contains information about the execution of a Job Release task on a compute node.

poolId.title: The id of the pool containing the compute node to which this entry refers.

nodeId.title: The id of the compute node to which this entry refers.

nodeUrl.title: The URL of the compute node to which this entry refers.

jobReleaseTaskExecutionInfo.title: Information about the execution status of the Job Release task on this compute node.
jobReleaseTaskExecutionInfo.description: This property is set only if the Job Release task has run on the node.

JobPreparationAndReleaseTaskExecutionInf.title: The status of the Job Preparation and Job Release tasks on a compute node.

osFamily.title: The Azure Guest OS family to be installed on the virtual machines in the pool.

targetOSVersion.title: The Azure Guest OS version to be installed on the virtual machines in the pool.
targetOSVersion.description: The default value is * which specifies the latest operating system version for the specified OS family.

currentOSVersion.title: The Azure Guest OS Version currently installed on the virtual machines in the pool. This may differ from targetOSVersion if the pool state is Upgrading.

CloudServiceConfiguration.title: The configuration for nodes in a pool based on the Azure Cloud Services platform.

publisher.title: The publisher of the Azure Virtual Machines Marketplace image.

offer.title: The offer type of the Azure Virtual Machines Marketplace image.

sku.title: The SKU of the Azure Virtual Machines Marketplace image.

version.title: The version of the Azure Virtual Machines Marketplace image.
version.description: A value of 'latest' can be specified to select the latest version of an image. If omitted, the default is 'latest'.

ImageReference.title: A reference to an Azure Virtual Machines Marketplace image.

enableAutomaticUpdates.title: Whether automatic updates are enabled on the virtual machine.
enableAutomaticUpdates.description: If omitted, the default value is true.

WindowsConfiguration.title: Windows operating system settings to apply to the virtual machine.

imageReference.title: A reference to the Azure Virtual Machines Marketplace image to use.

nodeAgentSKUId.title: The SKU of Batch Node Agent to be provisioned on the compute node.
nodeAgentSKUId.description: The Batch node agent is a program that runs on each node in the pool, and provides the command-and-control interface between the node and the Batch service. There are different implementations of the node agent, known as SKUs, for different operating systems.

windowsConfiguration.title: Windows operating system settings on the virtual machine.
windowsConfiguration.description: This property must not be specified if the imageReference property specifies a Linux OS image.

VirtualMachineConfiguration.title: The configuration for compute nodes in a pool based on the Azure Virtual Machines infrastructure.

subnetId.description: The ARM resource identifier of the virtual network subnet which the compute nodes of the pool will join. The virtual network must be in the same region and subscription as the Azure Batch account. This property can only be specified for pools created with a cloudServiceConfiguration.

NetworkConfiguration.description: The network configuration for a pool.

id.title: A string that uniquely identifies the pool within the account.
id.description: The id can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters including hyphens and underscores, and cannot contain more than 64 characters. It is common to use a GUID for the id.

displayName.title: The display name for the pool.

lastModified.title: The last modified time of the pool.

creationTime.title: The creation time of the pool.

state.title: The current state of the pool.

stateTransitionTime.title: The time at which the pool entered its current state.

allocationStateTransitionTime.title: The time at which the pool entered its current allocation state.

vmSize.title: The size of virtual machines in the pool. All virtual machines in a pool are the same size.

cloudServiceConfiguration.title: The cloud service configuration for the pool.
cloudServiceConfiguration.description: This property and virtualMachineConfiguration are mutually exclusive and one of the properties must be specified.

virtualMachineConfiguration.title: The virtual machine configuration for the pool.
virtualMachineConfiguration.description: This property and cloudServiceConfiguration are mutually exclusive and one of the properties must be specified.

resizeTimeout.title: The timeout for allocation of compute nodes to the pool.
resizeTimeout.description: This is the timeout for the most recent resize operation. The default value is 10 minutes.

resizeError.title: Details of any error encountered while performing the last resize on the pool.
resizeError.description: This property is set only if an error occurred during the last pool resize, and only when the pool allocationState is Steady.

currentDedicated.title: The number of compute nodes currently in the pool.

targetDedicated.title: The desired number of compute nodes in the pool.
targetDedicated.description: This property must have the default value if enableAutoScale is true. It is required if enableAutoScale is false.

enableAutoScale.title: Whether the pool size should automatically adjust over time.
enableAutoScale.description: If true, the autoScaleFormula property must be set. If false, the targetDedicated property must be set.

autoScaleFormula.title: A formula for the desired number of compute nodes in the pool.

autoScaleEvaluationInterval.title: A time interval for the desired AutoScale evaluation period in the pool.

autoScaleRun.title: The results and errors from the last execution of the autoscale formula.

enableInterNodeCommunication.title: Whether the pool permits direct communication between nodes.

networkConfiguration.title: The network configuration for the pool.

startTask.title: A task specified to run on each compute node as it joins the pool.

certificateReferences.title: The list of certificates to be installed on each compute node in the pool.

applicationPackageReferences.title: The list of application packages to be installed on each compute node in the pool.

maxTasksPerNode.title: The maximum number of tasks that can run concurrently on a single compute node in the pool.

taskSchedulingPolicy.title: How the Batch service distributes tasks between compute nodes in the pool.

metadata.title: A list of name-value pairs associated with the pool as metadata.

stats.title: Utilization and resource usage statistics for the entire lifetime of the pool.

CloudPool.title: A pool in the Azure Batch service.

id.title: A string that uniquely identifies the pool within the account.
id.description: The id can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters including hyphens and underscores, and cannot contain more than 64 characters. It is common to use a GUID for the id.

displayName.title: The display name for the pool.

vmSize.title: The size of virtual machines in the pool. All virtual machines in a pool are the same size.

cloudServiceConfiguration.title: The cloud service configuration for the pool.
cloudServiceConfiguration.description: This property and virtualMachineConfiguration are mutually exclusive and one of the properties must be specified.

virtualMachineConfiguration.title: The virtual machine configuration for the pool.
virtualMachineConfiguration.description: This property and cloudServiceConfiguration are mutually exclusive and one of the properties must be specified.

resizeTimeout.title: The timeout for allocation of compute nodes to the pool.

targetDedicated.title: The desired number of compute nodes in the pool.
targetDedicated.description: This property must have the default value if enableAutoScale is true. It is required if enableAutoScale is false.

enableAutoScale.title: Whether the pool size should automatically adjust over time.
enableAutoScale.description: If true, the autoScaleFormula property must be set. If false, the targetDedicated property must be set.

autoScaleFormula.title: A formula for the desired number of compute nodes in the pool.

autoScaleEvaluationInterval.title: A time interval for the desired autoscale evaluation period in the pool.

enableInterNodeCommunication.title: Whether the pool permits direct communication between nodes.

networkConfiguration.title: The network configuration for the pool.

startTask.title: A task specified to run on each compute node as it joins the pool.

certificateReferences.title: The list of certificates to be installed on each compute node in the pool.

applicationPackageReferences.title: The list of application packages to be installed on each compute node in the pool.

maxTasksPerNode.title: The maximum number of tasks that can run concurrently on a single compute node in the pool.

taskSchedulingPolicy.title: How the Batch service distributes tasks between compute nodes in the pool.

metadata.title: A list of name-value pairs associated with the pool as metadata.

PoolAddParameter.title: A pool in the Azure Batch service to add.

value.title: The list of applications available in the account.
